At the Louvre, tension builds over creation of new 'Mona Lisa' gallery
subhead: The Louvre-Nouvelle Renaissance architecture competition aims to create a room for Leonardo da Vinci's iconic painting and a new entrance for the Paris museum, which has seen a surge in visitors. Five teams have been shortlisted, none of which are French.

Ban on social media for under-15s: What we know about the government's plan
subhead: In addition to banning smartphones in high schools, a new law aims to block the youngest from accessing social media platforms. President Emmanuel Macron mentioned the topic during his New Year's address, and Parliament will debate the measure at the start of the year.

title: Egyptians become the leading African nationality to migrate to Europe
subhead: This year, Frontex, the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, recorded just over 16,000 irregular crossings by Egyptian nationals as of November 30, with most departing from Libyan shores to reach Italy, and some heading to Greece.

title: Between the US and China, the battle of hydrocarbons versus electrons
subhead: The energy divide continues to widen between a fossil-fuel-driven America and China, the global leader in low-carbon technologies. This rivalry is now playing out on the export front.

title: China's plan for London mega-embassy stokes controversy
subhead: Beijing acquired Royal Mint Court in 2018 with the aim of relocating its embassy in the United Kingdom there. Housing Minister Steve Reed had until December 10 to make a decision on this major project, but the deadline was postponed for the third consecutive time to January 2026.

Early Christian fresco depicting Jesus as the Good Shepherd discovered in Turkey
subhead: One month after Pope Leo XIV's visit, Turkish authorities announced the discovery in Iznik, Anatolia, of a depiction of Christ in a well-preserved burial chamber.

title: Iran's protests led by shopkeepers is shaking up the regime
subhead: The collapse of the rial currency deepens the economic struggles faced by retailers, who have taken to the streets in several major cities. Some universities in Tehran have also joined the mobilization, as economic grievances merge with increasingly political slogans.

title: 'I did it for the money, but I wasn't proud': Parties that hire 'dwarves' for entertainment
subhead: Hiring women or men of short stature to 'spice up' parties has become increasingly common in Europe in recent years. These practices raise both moral and legal questions.
